title: TrackifyJobs
summary: TrackifyJobs is a job tracking software I built for tracking and refining my job applications. It combines NLP resume scoring, automated follow-ups, and a streamlined dashboard to reduce stress and increase offer rates. The goal was to make application management effortless and intelligent.

sections.heading: Context & Problem
sections.body:
During internship season, I noticed peers were overwhelmed trying to manage dozens of applications with spreadsheets and notes. They often missed deadlines, forgot follow-ups, and sent generic resumes. Existing tools like Huntr or Trello weren't purpose-built and lacked intelligence.

I wanted to design something lean, fast, and helpful, so I made a dashboard tailored for technical job seekers that could score resumes, show what’s missing, and help plan actions.
bullets: Too many apps, too little feedback
No automated resume personalization or scoring
People forgot to follow up or didn’t know which job they were a good fit for

sections.heading: Design & UX Goals
sections.body:
From the start, the design needed to be clean, fast, and emotionally neutral — a workspace, not a gamified toy. I used Figma to wireframe dashboard flows that emphasize clarity and control. The color palette is muted with occasional highlight colors to reduce anxiety and help users focus.

Key flows like job entry, resume comparison, and reminders were designed to take under 60 seconds from start to finish. A sidebar layout made the dashboard feel anchored and familiar.
bullets: Neutral UI with subtle hierarchy cues
Minimized decision friction with focused CTA areas
Dark/light mode support for visual comfort

sections.heading: Technical Architecture
sections.body:
The stack is fully serverless: Next.js frontend (app router), Supabase for database + auth, Stripe for billing, and a custom Go API deployed via Vercel functions to run NLP-heavy resume parsing and scoring. I used Gemini Pro for understanding job descriptions and resumes.

Scoring works by embedding job description + resume content and computing a cosine similarity score. I cached results and used supabase edge functions to avoid latency issues. User state is stored via RLS-secured Postgres tables.
bullets: Next.js app router, Tailwind + custom components
Go backend for performance-critical logic
Gemini-powered resume analysis + cache layer
Supabase with RLS rules for secure user data access

sections.heading: Launch & Outcome
sections.body:
After a soft launch in university dev groups and subreddits, over 100 users signed up in the first month. Feedback centered around how helpful the resume scoring and timeline reminders were. Many users reported better interview callback rates and less stress.

Stripe was integrated with a simple pricing model: free tier with 10 resume analyses, $5/mo for unlimited scans and analytics. 11 users converted to paid in the first 30 days.
bullets: 100+ users in beta with consistent engagement
First month conversion: 11 paid out of 100
Strong retention from CS students and bootcamp grads

title: Regional Waste Services
summary: This local waste service provider website was originally built using an outdated WordPress template with inconsistent styling, poor contrast, broken navigation, and cluttered, low-quality images. I led a full redesign to improve accessibility, modernize the interface, and create a cleaner, more understandable experience across desktop, tablet, and mobile.

sections.heading: Initial Issues
sections.body: The original site was built on an outdated WordPress theme with inconsistent design patterns, broken links, and low-resolution images reused excessively. Navigation was unclear, with many dead-end pages and overlapping options. Core actions like checking service status or reaching support were hard to find. The visual hierarchy was weak, and the dashboard was overloaded with unnecessary options.

images.label: Legacy interface with unclear contrast and layout
Homepage cluttered with repeated service tiles

bullets: Outdated WordPress template with hardcoded styling
Broken or circular navigation flows
Low-contrast text and weak visual hierarchy
Pixelated and repetitive images
Overloaded dashboard with nonessential controls

sections.heading: Design Goals
sections.body: I focused on creating a cleaner, more intuitive layout with better spacing, clearer navigation, and modern visual styles. The design system was structured in Figma to support consistent typography, spacing, and button behavior. I updated image assets to be higher quality and ensured layout breakpoints worked across screen sizes. I also improved contrast and semantic HTML to move closer to accessibility best practices.

images.label: Style guide – typography, color, and layout tokens
Responsive layout structure across screen sizes

bullets: Cleaned up visual hierarchy and spacing
Structured reusable components in Figma
Improved navigation clarity and layout consistency
Replaced low-res assets with optimized image content
Improved contrast and markup for better accessibility

gallery.label: Redesigned service dashboard – desktop [Branding and names redacted]
Contact form layout with improved accessibility [Branding and names redacted]

title: Children's Dentistry
summary: This pediatric dental site, originally built in 2008, had outdated visual design, poor responsiveness, inconsistent navigation, and excessive use of clashing colors. I led a complete redesign to modernize the user experience while preserving some of the site's original charm. The new layout is responsive, accessible, and easier to navigate for parents and guardians.

sections.heading: Initial Issues
sections.body: The site had not been meaningfully updated since its creation in 2008. It suffered from accessibility issues including poor color contrast, unstructured text blocks, and layout problems on mobile devices. Many pages contained redundant or repeated navigation elements and there was little hierarchy to guide the user. The use of animal-themed visuals was playful but visually overpowering.

images.label: Legacy homepage layout with excessive color and weak hierarchy
Outdated services section with redundant links

bullets: Visual style inconsistent and cluttered
Poor mobile responsiveness and no layout scaling
Navigation with repeated or unclear link structures
Lack of accessible font and contrast settings
Animal imagery distracting rather than supportive

sections.heading: Design Goals
sections.body: The redesign focused on simplifying the structure, improving readability, and retaining visual personality in a more subtle usable way. I created a consistent color palette based on accessible standards, cleaned up navigation flows, and restructured the content to work fluidly across devices. Subtle background animal patterns were retained to reflect the site's original identity without overwhelming users.

images.label: Redesigned homepage with clear hierarchy and simplified layout
Design system with updated type colors and spacing rules

bullets: Structured and accessible layout across screen sizes
Reduced color palette for readability and visual coherence
Preserved thematic animal imagery in a toned down background role
Improved content structure and semantic HTML
Focused on ease of use for non technical users such as parents and guardians

gallery.label: Improved image layout and page flow for atmosphere section
Contact page with improved accessibility and form structure
FAQ layout with readable content blocks and refined spacing

title: CodeHub Website
summary: I led the UI/UX design and backend development for CodeHub, a student-run developer organization at the University of Georgia. The site serves as a central hub for forms, starter code, project showcases, and FAQs. I designed the full visual system and built the landing page frontend myself, while also contributing to backend architecture and helping coordinate integration work across the broader frontend. The focus was on creating a modular, accessible platform aligned with CodeHub’s mission to support beginner-friendly development and inclusive tech communities.

title: E-Commerce Product Title Classification
summary: This project explores scalable machine learning methods for classifying e-commerce product titles into 248 categories using a dataset of over 1.4 million entries. I implemented a preprocessing pipeline with TF-IDF vectorization, stopword removal, normalization, and feature selection to the top 10,000 tokens. I evaluated multiple classifiers, including Linear SVC, Logistic Regression, and Multinomial Naive Bayes, with class-weighted adjustments to handle imbalance. The study showed that Linear SVC consistently performed best on large-scale product categorization tasks, demonstrating the viability of ML for text classification in e-commerce systems.

title: BoomBox - Mood-Based Music Recommendation App
summary: BoomBox is a full-stack web app that recommends music based on the emotional tone of user-uploaded images. I led a team of two in building a system that uses Gemini for image sentiment analysis, the Spotify API for mood-aligned song selection, and Pinata for decentralized image storage. The app supports user authentication via Auth0 and stores user data in MongoDB. I designed the system architecture, handled API integration, and built the landing and core app frontend. Users can create and share playlists, with built-in group collaboration features that support co-curated music discovery.

title: Summit Management and Development
summary: Summit Management & Development is a land management and development company based in North Georgia. They needed a professional online presence to represent their growing portfolio and communicate their values of reliability, transparency, and attention to detail. I designed and developed a custom site that reflected their brand identity while improving accessibility and SEO performance.

sections.heading: Context & Problem
sections.body: Summit Management & Development did not previously have a website, relying only on word-of-mouth and email referrals. Without an online presence, they lacked a professional platform to showcase projects, explain services, or attract new clients. Competitors in the region had established, well-optimized sites that made Summit harder to find and trust online.
bullets: No online presence or client-facing materials
No SEO visibility or Google business integration
No consistent brand identity or message

sections.heading: Design & UX Goals
sections.body: My goal was to build a modern, trustworthy site that visually conveyed professionalism and stability. I designed a brand identity with an earthy, grounded color palette and geometric sans-serif typography. The layout prioritizes clarity—concise copy, wide spacing, and structured service sections. The homepage introduces the company mission, followed by a services overview and featured project highlights.
bullets: Calm, confident visual tone inspired by architectural lines
Simple, scannable content structure for clarity
Fully responsive design optimized for mobile and tablet
Optimized meta tags and schema markup for SEO visibility

sections.heading: Technical Implementation
sections.body: The website was built using Next.js with the App Router and styled using Tailwind CSS. I structured the content with reusable components for scalability, ensuring fast load times and responsive behavior. Image optimization was handled through Next.js static export, and performance was tuned to score 95+ across Google Lighthouse metrics. The site includes custom meta fields and Open Graph data for rich link previews.
bullets: Next.js + Tailwind CSS for modern static generation
Component-based structure for maintainability
Google Search Console setup and SEO indexing
Fast static deployment for near-instant load times

sections.heading: Outcome
sections.body: After launch, Summit gained a professional web presence that legitimized their brand and improved search ranking for regional keywords. The new site successfully captured leads through an optimized contact form and structured metadata. It now serves as a central marketing asset, referenced in their project proposals and client communications.
bullets: Established complete online presence with branded site
Strong initial SEO performance in regional search results
Improved client trust and lead generation
Streamlined content updates for future scalability

title: S.W.A.T Construction Company
summary: S.W.A.T. Construction is a Georgia-based contractor specializing in framing, drywall, and acoustical systems for commercial buildings. The company had no digital presence, so I created their complete brand identity and website from the ground up, from logo direction and design system to content layout and deployment.

sections.heading: Context & Problem
sections.body: For over 25 years, S.W.A.T. had built high-quality commercial structures across the Southeast, yet lacked an online identity to reflect their expertise. Without a website or consistent branding, they were invisible to potential clients searching locally for construction partners. The goal was to establish a trustworthy digital presence that communicated their legacy of reliability and craftsmanship.
bullets: No digital footprint or discoverable online presence
Outdated communication limited to referrals and word of mouth
No cohesive brand identity across print or proposals

sections.heading: Design & Brand Direction
sections.body: The design needed to convey professionalism and strength while staying simple and timeless. I built a brand palette based on deep charcoal, clean white, and a signature construction red accent. The typography combines geometric sans-serifs for clarity with subtle contrast in headings to feel architectural. Layouts were designed to feel grounded and symmetrical, using high-quality imagery of projects and clean grid spacing.
bullets: Minimal design language inspired by construction precision
Strong brand red accent to convey energy and reliability
Hero imagery framed by geometric grid overlays for visual structure
Consistent spacing and modular section rhythm across devices

sections.heading: Website Structure & Development
sections.body: The site was developed using Next.js and Tailwind CSS for clean performance and scalability. I designed custom sections for services, company overview, industry specialization, testimonials, and a contact form. Each block is modular, meaning future service pages can be added easily without refactoring. I also optimized for SEO, accessibility, and Core Web Vitals, achieving 100 on desktop for all scores.
bullets: Next.js + Tailwind CSS for efficient static site generation
Responsive layout across all modern breakpoints
SEO metadata and OpenGraph integration for discoverability
Contact form integrated with Netlify Forms for direct submissions

sections.heading: Outcome
sections.body: The new site established S.W.A.T.’s digital identity and positioned them competitively among regional contractors. The homepage emphasizes their legacy and service clarity while providing strong visual credibility. Early feedback from clients noted how the website reflected their professionalism and quality of work. The company now references the site in all proposals and client outreach.
bullets: First professional web presence in company history
Optimized SEO structure for local construction searches
Consistent lead generation via form submissions
Strong client feedback on design clarity and brand cohesion
